title: Tonkotsu Soup

ingredients.name: pork femurs, split to expose marrow

steps: The night before, or at least 6 hours before cooking, soak your neck bones and femurs in water in a cold, non-reactive vessel (technically optional, but results in whiter appearance).

When ready to cook, add your neck bones and femurs to a pot with fresh water. Bring to a boil, then down to a simmer, and skim the scum that rises to the top. Do this for 15-20 minutes, or until little scum is rising. The scum goes through several phases - you'll know when it's done rising. This blanch is integral for white tonkotsu.
Strain the bones from the blanching liquid. Discard the liquid.
Scrub and clean the bones under running water, removing any black or dirty looking particulate that may be on the outside of the bones or in crevices.
Add your now clean bones to a pot.
Cook at a medium boil for 18 hours, stirring frequently.
If using, add aromatics to the broth in the last hour.

To finalize the emulsion, add the soup to a blender and blend on high for 30 seconds, being careful to gradually bring the blender to high to avoid splashing. You can also use a hand blender for 5 minutes, though the emulsion won't be as strong.
notes: Tonkotsu is a paitan (cloudy soup) of pork bones.
This is the basic tonkotsu approach that most restaurants use.
Some restaurants add new bones midway through cooking or use different bones like heads or ribs, but the method is essentially the same: cook bones to death and emulsify everything.
Can be made in pressure cooker: Up to 2 hours at pressure.
Can be stored for up to a week in the fridge or 6 months in the freezer.
From 'The Book of Ramen' - Chapter 2: Soup
